div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindlei Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

THURSDAY DECEMBER 28, 1905
MINING IN EGYPT
The references to the new Mining Depart- ment in the Financial Adviser's most inter- esting Budget Note will be of considerable interest to all who believe in the future of Egyptian mining, and bear ample testimony to the readiness of the Government to support all genuine attempts to develop the mineral industry of the country. The great area of the regions in which ancient workings have been found, and the probability that modern ap- liances will revive an industry practically abandoned since the early middle ages, if not earlier, have "induced the expenditure of large sums of money within the next few years for further exploration and develop- ment work, most of which money will be deriv- ed from sources outside the country and spent in it." To this end a Department of Mines has been formed. Mr. Wells, the Inspector General of Mines, has an admirable record as a practical mining engineer, and his knowledge of the industry and his energy in scouring the Arabian and Lybian desert have already borne fruit, and we understand that during his last leave be examined various methods of motor transport with a view to improving communi- cation between the mining areas and the Nile. New tri-car motors have been adopted which have stood their trials over very rough ground with real success, and it is stated that should the development of the mining industry be such as to demand it, a regular system of motor communication will be adopted. To prevent individuals or parties going to or returning from the mines being in any way molested, either by Bedouins, who, to do them justice, have hitherto been well behaved, or by stray ruffians like the bandit who fell to a coast guard patrol a few weeks ago, a special force of desert police has been organised. The measure is a timely one and will have the development of mining may possibly result in labour troubles. A strike or an affray at a mining camp would lose half its danger if a police force were held in readiness to start at once from Edfon to the scene of disturbance and patrols were known to be constantly moving in the desert.
The development of motor transport and the possibility of adapting strong and fast motor cars to desert work opens up fascinating cistas of the future of the desert tracts of North Africa. Perhaps in the next generation we shall see motor excursions to Siwa posts, wells, and artificial cases created, thanks to the development of the machine, and the Arabian and Syrian deserts yielding up their mineral wealth while their cases are as prosper- ous as in Roman days. Fanciful Well, the use of motor cars for purposes of cross-country travel and transport is only in its infancy, the future may show us all these things or more, and bolds fascinating vistas or adventure: the Sahara tamed by French motor-cars and the Inspector-General of the Egyptian Department of Mines calling, let us hope with a trusty escort, on the Sheikh el-Sedussi at the Zawia of Kutra.
THE NATIVE PRESS
THE EGYPTIAN QUESTION
In a leading article, our native contemporary "Al Zaher" remarks:-Many people think that the Egyptian question is closed forever, and that the Anglo-French Agreement of April, 1904, has put an end to Egyptian hopes, thus causing many to despair in regard to England's withdrawal from Egypt. Those people obtain confirmation intheir belief on seeing the silence of the native Press on the subject, but they are mistaken. The egyptian Question now is in the same position as it was in 1882. Statesmen are sparing no efforts to call the attention of Europe to the question, and the final decision is still to come. M. Freyeinet, the ex-Minister of the French Foreign Office, published a few months ago a book entitled "The Egyptian Question" in which he dealt with all the details of this subject. He declared that France had, for- tunately, done nothing to affirm the British authority in Egypt, and that the British Occu- pation has still the same features as befire, without any additional guarantees. Thus the Egyptian Question still exists and the eventual withdrawal of the Occupation must be look- ed for.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Khartoum-Kassala Road. The Sudan Government is constructing a route from Khartoum to Kassala.
A Foundling. A newly born child was found by the police near Mustapha Pasha yesterday and removed to hospital.
National Bank of Egypt. M. Armando Mustaki has been appointed manager of the sub-agency of the National Bank of Egypt in the Midan quarter of Alex- andria.
Burned to Death. A native girl of 6, diving in the Custom house quarter, was burned to death yesterday through her clothes catching fire from a candle which she was holding in her hand.
Fire in Cairo. A fire brook out in a home above Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi’s establishment in the Esbekish quarter of Cairo yesterday, but was rapidly extinguished by the Fire Brigade.

Mena House Case. The claim to pre-emption brought by Dr. Rifky and the Princess, his wife, against Mr. Nungovich in regard to the purchase of Mena House Hotel came before the Cairo Mixed Court on Tuesday.

Railway Fatality. To save a third-class fire from Cairo to Suez, a native got on the roof of a carriage of the train which left Bab-el-Hadid station at 7 a.m. on Saturday. At Benha his head came into collision with the bridge and he was killed on the spot.

International Chamber of Commerce. The International Chamber of Commerce at Cairo met last night to elect a president in place of M. Leroux, resigned. Mr. Scott- Dalgleish, vice-president, was elected president by 12 votes out of 18 present, and Mr. Dessalles D’Epinoix was elected vice-president.

Quadrille Dance Party. A quadrille dance party will be given by the warrant officers, staff sergeants, and sergeants of the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers in the Mess-room, Mustapha, on Monday, 1st January, dancing to commence at 8 p.m. Invitation tickets most be presented at the door.

A Good Scheme. The Government proposes to supplement each year the Cassel charity by the establish- ment of one or more permanent ophthalmic hospitals, until every moudirieh shall have its own hospital. One will be built next year for a sum of L.E. 4,000. The annual charge will be about L.E. 5,000.

Union Artistique Francaise. The above society will give a dramatic per- formance in their hall in Stamboul-street this evening, commencing at 9. The programme consists of three parts, i.e., La Femme a conference in one act, Monsieur Badin, a one-act comedy by Courteline, and Les Boulin grins, also a one-act comedy by Courteline.

New British Club. Donations of £5 each in aid of the founding of the new British Club at Alexandria have been received from the London and Lancashire Life Assurance Co. and the General Fire and Accident Assurance Corporation. It is to be hoped that the other insurance companies will follow this excellent example.

Appointment for Dr. Sandwith. Dr. Sandwith has been appointed Lecturer on Tropical Diseases in St. Thomas’s Medical School. Dr. Sandwith’s wide experience of the subject should be a sufficient guarantee, if it were necesary, for the distinct advantage which St. Thomas’s students in the future will derive by the addition to their teaching staff of so eminent an authority as Dr. Sand- with. Every London Medical School in the near future will be compelled to have a Lecturer on Tropical Diseases, and this is not surprising when we come to consider that each hospital sends a large number of its old students into the Services, and to practise abroad. It is, therefore, essential for these men to have at least some idea of the nature of the diseases which are commonly met with in the Tropics.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
SOME EXTRACTS.
PUBLIC BUILDINGS EXPENDITURE.
div.p: In his Note on the 1905 Budget, the Financial Adviser says :— Roughly speaking, it may be said that Egypt is actually spending from L.E. 300,000 to L.E. 400,000 annually on public buildings ; not, I think, an extravagant sum, having re- gard to the revenue of the country and the fact that everything has to be provided ab initio, hospitals, post offices, prisons, asylums, schools, police stations, to say nothing of Gou- vernorats, and other Government buildings of practically every description.
Of course in the above figures are not in- cluded great works of public utility of a remunerative nature, which are charged to Reserve Fund.

div.div:
THE ENGLISH G. P. O.
As to penny postage between Egypt and the United Kingdom, the Financial Adviser says :—"For years past the Egyptian Go- vernment has been urging the adoption of this reform, but had hitherto failed to shake the non possumus attitude of the British portal authorities.”

div.head: THE COST OF THE ARMY.
div.p: In remarking on the increase in the budget of the Ministry of War Sir Vincent Corbett says:—

L.E 50,000 represents a portion of Army expenditure hitherto refunded by the Sudanese Government and which will for the future be borne by Egypt. Seeing that the Egyptian Army in the Sudan is employed to all intents and purposes in guarding the Egyptian frontier and that its movements are dictated by Egyp- tian interests, it seemed unfair any longer to burden the nascent revenue of the Sudan with so heavy a charge. The sum thus set free will be employed in the interior development of the country, thus hastening the day, not, I am confident, very far distant, when the re- venue of the Sudan will not only suffice for its wants, but enable it to make a return on the considerable sums invested by Egypt in that country.

div.head: THE CAISSE CRITICISED.
div.p: He criticises The Caisse de la Dette for having only reduced its expenses by L. E. 2,500 in the following strong terms:—

It is regrettable that the last named institu- tion should not have seen its way to effecting still larger economies, as its work is now practically limited to the "payment of the coupon out of sums automatically paid into its coffers by the State.

div.div:
MUNICIPAL COMMISSIONS.
Sir Vincent makes the following remarks on the provincial commissions : — The local Municipal Commissions, which constituted a sort of middle term between governmental and municipal control of local business, are working farly well, but owing to the regime of the Capitulations, which hampers local reform at every turn, they are unable to develop as satisfactorily as could be wished. The privileges of foreigners render local taxa- tion to any reasonable extent an impossibility, with the result that there is an ever-increasing demand under this head for aid from the funds of the central Government.

EGYPT AND GERMANY.
THE POSTAL TARIFF. The "Kölnische Zeitung" publishes a com- munication which, although dated from Cairo, probably emanates from Berlin, regarding a readjustment of the postal tariff between Ger- many and Egypt. According to this communi- cation, the Egyptian Government has entered into communication with other countries for the purpose of bringing about a reduction of its postal tariff, similar to that recently arrang- ed with England in order to show that Egypt has not become a British colony. The German Government is now considering the matter. Probably penny postage will be introduced between Germany and Egypt.

div.head: THE GORDON COLLEGE.
ANNUAL REPORT.
THE PAST YEAR EVENTFUL.
div.p: Mr. James Currie, Director of Education in the Sudan, and Principal of the Gordon Memorial College at Khartoum, reporting on the work of the institution for 1904, makes mention of the great loss the collnge has sustained by the death of Mr. Alfred Spalding Harvey, the hon. secretary, and of his own indebtedness to Mr. Harvey’s sagacity and wide knowledge of men and things. The past year, he says, has been rather an eventful one, and several important decisions have been taken, though these perhaps may be said to represent the development of exiting agencies and do not constitute fresh departures. The college, apart from the laboratories, as has been explained in previous reports, has so far been divided into three sections: a Primary School, a Training College for Schoolmasters and Judges in the Mohamedan Courts, and the instructional workshops. The Primary School, attended by about 180 boys, has now assumed a final form. The curriculum, in the event of a a boy being unable to carry his education further, extends over four years, and is calculat- ed to fit him to fill some minor Government post, such as junior telegraphist, petty clerk, or land measurer. Apart from the normal increase of numbers the only point worthy of special notice is the prosperity of the boarding- house. This is now quite fall, some 25 boys be- ing in residence, of whom all but two are genuine inhabitants of the Sudan and many of them members of very well-known and influential families. The Military School, intended for Sudanese cadets, prospective officers in the black battalions, is now open and appears to have made a good beginning. It has been liberally treated in the natter of staff. The Training College has also prospered, and the progress reported in last year’s report has been well sustained. By the end of 1906 it will be possible to judge whether or not the ex- periment is going to be successful and whe- ther these young sheikhs have during their period of training acquired sufficient know- lege of Mohamedan law to administer it efficiently, and sufficient general culture to conduct that administration in accordance with the principles that must obtain in all countries where British influence is paramount. Every- thing possible is being done by the staff of lecturers to make the experiment a success, and one can only patiently watch results. The object of the workshops is to provide practical instruction in carpentering, fitting, smith’s work, moulder’s work, cotton ginning, and a primary stage of mechanical engineering, which includes the management and repair of oil and steam engines with electricity and water pressure as adjuncts, pumping machinery, and turning. Ultimately only boys who have passed through the Elementary Vernacular Schools will be admitted, but at present the supply of these is too small to fill the work- shops, and many boys have been allowed to enter whose general education does not come up to the standard required. In addition to their practical work all the boys spend six hours a week continuing their previous educa- tion. It is Mr. Currie’s opinion that consequent on the general policy of the Sudan and Egyp- tian Governments the economic development of the Sudan is likely to be more rapid than anyone four years ago could have considered possible.

Sir Reginald Wingate, in forwarding lht| report to the Earl of Cromer, says that a very important step has been taken in initiating a system of secondary education and starting a small engineering school for the training of over- seers of works and land surveyors. The college is fortunate in having the services of a very competent instructor in Mr. Rhodes. The in- vestigation work performed in the "Wellcome” Laboratories under the able direction of Dr. Andrew Balfour during the past year has been of increasing value and interest, more especially in regard to the causes of sleeping sickness, both in human beings and in animals. In this connection the recent journey of Dr. Sheffield Neave on the Upper Nile and in the Bahr el Ghazal should furnish further valuable information. The chemical analyses by Dr. Beam of the waters of the various rivers in the Sudan are also of considerable interest and importance.

div.div:
“ALI BABA" AT SUEZ.
AMATEUR PANTOMIME.
A SEASONABLE PERFORMANCE.
It was a happy idea that led the members of the E. T. C. Mess at Suez to give so season- able and enjoyable an entertainment as a pantomime on Boxing Day. The subject chosen was Ali Baba, described as a pantomime pot pourri in 2 acts; but far from being the old story, it devolved itself into a topical and distinctly humorous legend from the pen of Mr. O. D. Harris. Music was introduced throughout, and the parodies on well-known songs were much appreciated.
The story, which deserves mention if only for its originality, is briefly this: Ali Baba, the captain of the 40 thieves, comes down from the Attaca mountains, where he lives, in order to smuggle some hashish from a ship due that day. Unfortunately, on his way from the hills, his motor breaks down and he is forced to put up at the Suez Gulf Club, where he is made much of in the guise of a stranger, and getting into conversation with Aladdin, the coastguard chief, Ali Baba learns the password "Open Sesame," which will enable him to pass the sentinels along the docks road on his return from the 14th of July celebrations at Port Tewfik, the occasion he has chosen for smuggling the booty. The second act discovers Ali Baba at the dance, but in a sore plight, for he has forgotten the password, but he manages after much difficulty in his conversation with a French lady to induce her to take a small parcel he resourcefully names chocolates. Just aa Ali is kissing his hand in tender farewell to his innocent accomplice, his wife Morgiana turns up and charges her husband with infidelity. Ali’s explanations fail to convince the injured Morgiana, who straightway goes to the autho- rities for a divorce, when Ali’s calling as a desperado is soon revealed. Circumstantial evidence, however, foils to convict Ali Baba, and his fair accomplice has passed through the canal on her errand in a special tug. Pursuit is apparently useless, for we learn in the con- cluding lines that the famous waterway is closed owing to the explosion of the Chatham, and we hope for the sake of the story that the State railways did not exist in the days of Ali Baba and his forty thieves.
As regards the individual artists, Mr. Dug- more, as Cinderella, repeated his former suc- cesses in the role of the "giddy young thing" of the fairer sex, whose game of bumple-puppy in the first act can only be described as "great." The lengthy role of Aladdin was made much of by Mr. G. A. Evans, who fully entered into the humorous side of the arduous duties of a conscientious coastguard official. Mr. Menzies, described on the programme as the wife of the deceased Blue Beard, was quite a fascinating if youthful creature, but we do not wish to enquire at what age this charming damsel became allied to her faithless husband. As Jack the Giant Killer, Mr. F. W. Hamilton showed much cleverness in dealing with the awkward situations brought about by his zealous compatriot, Aladdin. Mr. Counsell, as Morgiana, and Mr. Mansell, as Friday, under- took minor parts, but far from casting any reflection on their capabilities let it be said that they were quite up to the standard of Mr. Harris’s supporters. There only remains Mr. O.D. Harris in the title role. We cannot say too much of his rendering of Ali Baba and his two songs. " The captain of the 40 thieves " and the " Local Limericks " intro- duced in the second act, created roars of laughter. We think it a pity that Mr. Harris does not find wider scope for his energies.
The piece was well mounted and the effec- tive scenery was due to the clever brush of Mr. G. A. Evans. The costumes, especially those of the female characters, lacked nothing in style, and Mme Gasser is to be congra- tulated on her work. Other dresses and wigs were by W. Waller of London.
THE COLD WEATHER. The weather at Suez is exceptionally cold this year. A few days ago snow was visible on the highest peaks of the Attaka mountains, about 20 miles south of Suez. This was re- ported by several homeward bound steamers, and the phenomenon was visible with a teles- cope from Suez.

NOTES FROM HELOUAN.
SCARCITY OF HOUSES.
THE RACES. - FISH AND MUSIC.
(From our correspondent).
Helouan, Wednesday. The prospects for the races are bright, and the arrangements are practically complete already. The course, which is very wide in extent, is in fine condition, and extensive im- provements have been carried out in the enclosure behind the hotel for the comfort of spectators and the convenience of all concerned in the races. The grand stands afford a splen- did view of the whole course, while the issue of each contest will be apparent to all without the slightest difficulty. I also understand that special train arrangements have been made for the day by the railway company.
SCARCITY OF HOUSES.
In spite of the fact that up to the present the season has not been up to the average, it is reported that visitors desirous of renting houses in Helouan are in several cases unable to find the necessary accommodation. Some residents prophesy that in future visitors to Helouan will be confined to those requiring the benefits of the sulphur baths, while others will go on to Luxor and Assouan. Whether that will be the case or not in the future, at present there is a demand for houses which the provision is not able to supply. New houses are being built in several parts of the town and others are being enlarged, so that soon there ought to be a supply equal to the demand. During the present week, American and other visitors have begun to arrive, and rooms have been engaged in advance by many who have already gone to Assouan.
“MA FISH."
Helouan offers opportunities for an enter- prising fishmonger able and willing reasonably to supply demands daily. We are not altoge- ther left without fish, of course, and the prin- cipal establishments can always obtain supplies from Cairo, but those who buy locally have sometimes to content themselves with very coarse fish or to go without any at all. Some of the gentlemen who tell fish stories in the hotels might turn the tables on those in- credulous persons who smile at them, by turning their attention to this matter now and then. People could not then say "ma fish," for the fish would be there!
CONCERNING TONES.
The band which plays selections of music in Helouan on Sundays undoubtedly breaks the monotony of life here, but until one becomes habituated to music so plentiful in what was formerly called discord, one some- how cannot help preferring the monotone to many tones.
'XMAS AT THE TEWFIK.
'Xmas was celebrated at the Tewfik Palace Hotel in the good old English fashion. The larger hall was decorated with flags and ever- greens and a motto, "Merry 'Xmas to All." An excellent dinner was served at 7.30, after which there was a Cindalerla dance, one or two veterans being well to the front. An Italian string band "played during and after dinner. Among the many guests we noticed that Dr. and Mrs. Bentley entertained a large party, Miss Smail a party of 4, Mr. Wyllie a party of 4, and Mr. Grant also entertained a few friends.
'XMAS AT MENA.
’Xmas Day brought quite a crowd of Cairo people to Mena House Hotel for luncheon and tea, but the ’Xmas dinner was the crowning point of the day. The well-known dining-hall was tastefully decorated with evergreens, and almost gave one the impression of being in a palm garden. Little coloured lamps were studded all over the large and small galleries, and happy parties one after another entered the fairy scene with the sound of soft music greeting them. We will not dwell on the details of the excellent dinner that was served, but we must, at least, mention the fact that when the electric light was switched off and the ice brought in illuminated, the visitors and guests staying at the hotel, with one accord, broke into hearty applause. After the dessert the choir of the hotel staff gave '"Teure Heimat" by special request of the visitors, and, if anything, did better than on 'Xmas Eve.
Mr. Sheldon Amos had a party of 10 for dinner, Mr. Royle a party of 6, Mr. John Ross one of 7, and Dr. Wakeling, the popular resi- dent physician of Mena House, a party of 24, besides many others.
On Boxing Day the small dance at Mena House was well attended, which was surpris- ing, considering that many similar functions took place that night. We noticed among the visitors Lieut.-Col. and Mrs. Ludlow, Major And Mrs. Delavoy, Miss Curry, Mrs. John Diamaut, Mr. and Mrs. John Ross, Miss Berry, Miss Leigh, Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Johnstone, Miss Wetherhill, Mr. Larchester and his party, Miss Mulholland, Miss Tunley, Miss Thomson, Mrs. Miles and the Misses Miles, Miss Duncan, Miss Darby, Mr. Alain C. White and party, Mr. Ward Boys, Mrs. Stephens, Mr. P. M. Stout, Mr. C. Ratamau, Mr. E. A. Bowen, Mr. Livingston, Baron M. Ramel, and many others.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS. The M.M. steamer Congo arrived at Mar- sailles from Alexandria yesterday morning.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Lord Cromer has become a Vice-President of the Society for the Preservation of the Wild Fauna of the Empire.
Sir Elwin Palmer’s condition, we are glad to learn, shows a decided improvement.
Lady Colvin leaves Marseilles for Egypt to- morrow.
The many friends of that popular officer, late of the Egyptian Army, the Hon. Alex- ander Hore-Ruthven, V.C. will be interested to learn that the only appointment that the new Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Lord Aberdeen, has yet made to his personal staff is that of Mr. Ruthven. It may be remembered that it was only in September last that Mr. Ruthven obtained the billet of military secretary to Lord Dudley, and now his successor has taken him on again. This appointment is very popular and everyone in Dublin is glad. Mr. Ruthven is the second son of the 8th Baron Ruthven and commanded the Camel Corps Detachment at the battle of Gedaref.
The insignia of the Legion of Honor were handed to H. E. the Governor of Alexandria to-day by a delegate of the French Consulate.
Mr. Mitchell Innes has returned from his trip, in which he was accompanied by Mr. Wells, to the mining areas on the Red Sea.

Sevingsten, Mr. Carey, Mr. Von Bibes, Mr. Schwambern, Messrs. Wirt and Voigh. Lord Talbot de Malahide and a party of two. MM. P. and J. de Vilmorin, Mme. P. de Vilmorin the Marquise de Champagné, Comte de St. Exupéry, and MM. R and P. le Cerf and de Cortan leave Khartoum on the 5th prox. by two special steamers for a two months' sporting trip to the Abyssinian frontier up the Blue Nile.
Mr. Duncan W. Morris, of Messrs. Whitehead, Morris and Co., the well-known London stationary and printing firm, arrived at Port Said this morning by the Orient liner Ortena. He proceeded to Cairo, and will remain in Egypt for a visit of some length, in order to look after the branches his firm has established in Alexandria and Cairo.
We deeply regret to report the death of Sister Marie, of the French Hospital,cCairo, who died on Sunday last of consumption, con- tracted in the execution of her duties as nurse. During 22 years of devoted work she had won the admiration and love of all who knew har, and her death was in keeping with a life of duty.
Mr. Grant, of Messrs. Grant, Bondi and Chinn, has left the Hutchinson Nursing Home, Cairo, after a severe attack of pleurisy, for Helouan, and will complete his cure by going to Assouan, or still further south in March in search of warmth.
Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Saïd, we notice Canon Holland, of Canterbury, Major L'Estrange Johnstone, Emin Bey, Turkish Consul General at Bombay, Lient. Col. SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL.
The meeting of the Railway Institute and D Co. K. R. R. Corps, at Boulac, was witnessed by a good number of spectators. The visitors were the first to score, but a few minutes later the home team equalised. When well into the first half, Smith scored the home team’s second goal after a brilliant piece of individual play. Up to the interval play was very fast and the game was fairly open. The second half was a trifle tame, for both sets or for- wards lacked combination, and the and came without any further scoring. The home de- fence had plenty of work to do in the last part of the game, especially the custodian, Mr. R. Appleby, who was in fine form between the posts. ---------------------

div.head: ﻿TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS.
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
SEVERE FIGHTING IN MOSCOW
CONSPICUOUS BRAVERY OF WOMEN
div.p: Moscow, December 27.
The system of barricades is being extended and the rebels are still unsubdued. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, December 27.

All the members of the executive committee of the armed revolutionary bands here, num- bering 49, were arrested during the evening of the 25th inst, including the engineer Sohul- mann, their leader. Plans, documents, bombs, and arms were also seized.
Part of the first corps returning from Man- churia will be sent to Livonia.
Revolutionary fighting has taken place at Kharkoff, causing over two hundred casualties.
Sixty or seventy of the most dangerous members of the revolutionary party were arrested here yesterday evening. This marks their failure in effecting a rising similar to that at Moscow. (Reuter)
Moscow, December 27.

Yesterday’s fighting here was most severe, and continues to-day. Strong rebel forces are operating in different quarters, throwing up barricades, making surprise attacks, and fight- ing from houses, which they seize indiscrimin- ately, abandoning them as soon as they are bombarded. The artillery is therefore contin- ually engaged. The women have shown conspicuous bravery and ferocity. The Nicholas terminus is ablaze. It transpires that half the garrison is confined to barracks for fear that they should join the insurgents. Reinforce- ments have arrived. (Reuter)
Moscow, December 27.
Reinforcements have arrived. It is hoped that order will soon be restored. (Havas)

div.head: THE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 27.

The new electoral law for the National Assembly has been promulgated. It maintains the principle of indirect elections. The procla- mation points out that most Western nations do not possess universal suffrage, nevertheless a very extended suffrage, especially in cities, has been granted.
A large force of troops has left for Lithuania. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION
ANXIETY AS TO GERMAN POLICY.
div.p: London, December 27.

The Sultan of Morocco has refused to consent to the Conference being held at Madrid. He will agree only to Algeciras or Tangier. The German policy in Morocco continues to be viewed with uneasiness and even anxiety on the Continent. It is note- worthy that, to-day, the "Times,” in an article of three columns, in comparing the mobilising capacities of France and Germany, and their relative forces, is of opinion that France is much more formidable now than in 1870.
Paris, December 27.
The "Temps” says that Emperor William has given Count Tattenbach conciliatory in- structions. (Havas)

div.head: A MUNICIPAL CONGRESS.
L. C. C. CHAIRMAN’S SCHEME.
div.p: London, December 27.

Inspired by the success of the visit of the Paris Municipality, the chairman of the Lon- don County Council has promulgated a scheme, for a congress of representatives from the capitals of the civilised world, being an inter- national conferenoe between municipalities of capitals which hav ae population of over half- a-million. The primary objest is to study drainage, education, and the housing of the working classes. (Reuter)

div.head: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION IN FRANCE.
div.p: PARIS, December 27.
The election of the President of the Republic will take place on January 16. (Havas)

div.head: THE JEWISH RACE IN EGYPT
div.p: A correspondent, Mr. T. D. Hall, writing to the “Manchester Guardian" on the subject of the recent outrages on the Jews in Russia, points out that while the feeling of antagonism towards a race so unlike the rest of the world undoubtedly gained intensity and bitterness from misdirected Christian sentiment and passion, long before the Christian faith had gained ascendancy the streets of cities inhabited by Jews bad been reddened with Jewish blood. Alexandria under the Ptolemies was a second Jewish capital—two of its five divisions being inhabited by Jews. The whole population of Jews in Egypt at the commencement of the Christian era is estimated at about a million; and they received high marks of consideration first from the Greek sovereigns and afterwards from Augustus. Yet, though Egypt was foe them a land of comparative privilege, their position even here was far from being an enviable one.

The contempt with whioh they looked down upon the miserable superstitions of Egypt," says Professor James Drummond, “and the peculiar customs which served as a barrier between them and their neighbours, excited the ani- mosity of the people among whom they lived; and they were subject from time to time, as so often in later ages and in other lands, to brutal outbursts of popular passion and vio- lence, and occasionally to the more formal outrages of persecution directed by the Govern- ment” (Hibbert Lectures, "Philo,” Intro.):

An outbreak which occurred in the reign of Claudius— under a Roman Governor as brutally cruel and tyrannical as the one who shortly afterwards goaded the Jews of Palestine into the despairing rebellion which ended in the fall of Jerusalem (70 a.d.) recalls the worst features of the Odessa massacres. "Whole families were burned, no pity being shown to either age or sex, and many perished by tor- tures, if possible, still more horrible” (iv. p. 9). Nor was this an isolated occurrence. There was a renewal of all the horrors in the reign of the ferocious madman Caligula. For no other face does the grave Tacitus show a tithe of the hatred and contempt which he pours upon the unfortunate people in what professes to be a purely historical narrative. Already in Egypt a race "abhorred of the gods,” obeying, through the deliberate purpose of their legislator, laws diametrically opposed to those of other na- tions, and cherishing an inborn hatred to all other races, and tolerating every abomination among themselves—such is the picture, barely relieved by the single virtue of fidelity and compassion for each other, which he gives of a nation whioh he utterly failed to compre- hend. If this was the temper of the educated -restrained from violence by self-respect and philosophy,—what forbearance was to be ex- expected from a brutal rabble, ever on the look out for pillage?

Even the horrible cruelties of Nero, though directed especially against the Christians, probably had their foundation in this prevail- ling hatred and contempt. To Nero and his Court Christianity would appear simply as a variety of Judaism, and the early Christian Church, even in Rome, was no doubt largely Jewish. Moreover, its author was a Jew, and a Jew who had been found deserving of capital punishment by a Roman Governor.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS.
ANNUAL MEETING ADJOURNED.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, was held on the 21st inst. at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., Sir Auckland Colvin (the chairman of the company) presiding.
The secretary (Mr. F. J. Horne) having read the notice calling the meeting,

The chairman said: I think the circular you will have received with the notice convening this meeting clearly explains the reasons for calling you together to-day. We have seen for some time past that the interval between Sep- tember 30th (which date has up to the present been the termination of our financial year) and December 31st would be too short, as the size of our undertakings increased, to prepare and have audited by the Government and the company’s auditors the revenue accounts and balance-sheet in time to present to the pro- prietors at the general meeting which, in order to comply with the requirements of the Companies Acts, must be held in each year— that is to say, under the existing arrangements, on or before Deoember 31st. The purchase of the Helouan Railway has thrown upon our accounts and audit departments a mass of additional work which has brought matters to a climax, and we have been compelled to defer the publication of the report and accounts for a month. This meeting will therefore be adjourn- ed to January 30th next and the usual report and accounts will be poe-ed to the shareholders early in that month. For the reasons I have given you, and also because September 30th is a most inconvenient date for closing the accounts of the company, as it is the busiest season of the year, we have decided to alter the date of closing the accounts from Septem- ber 30th to March 31st, which will allow us more time in future. A further general meeting will therefore be convened in 1906, when a half yearly report and accounts will he issued, after which they will be published annually as heretofore. I will now therefore move that this meeting be adjourned until January 30th, 1906.
Sir Charles William Fremantle seconded the resolution, and it was carried unanimously.

div.head: Circulaire N. de Vries et Boutigny.
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 27 decembre.
Apres le chomage de trois jours determine par les letes de Noel, notre marche des valeurs a fait ce matin une recuverture assez ferme, sinon tres animee.
La tendance est bonne sur presque toutes les valeurs, mais les transactions sont relativement peu nombreuses.
La National Bank et l'Agricole sont sou- teunes a leurs cours precedents. L’action Credit Foncier Hechit a 777-778, et la Behera a 35 1/2.
En bonne demande, l’action Ciments, dont nous parlous plus loin, gagne 6 francs a 73 et les dividendes 2 francs a 20.
L'action Bourse Khediviale du Cairo ouvre a £ 151 pour cloturer a 138 acheteurs.
Dans le groupe des hotels, de forts achats en Nungovich, antici qu’a Alexandrie, poussent le cours a 11 1/16.
Rien de particulier a signaler sur les antres titres.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian sont demandes a 28 sh. et les Cotton Mills a 5 sh. 9.
Nous avons deja donne d'interessants details concernant les Splendid Hotels, dont on com- mence a s'occuper serieusement a la Bourse et qui meritent mieux que le cours actuel.

Les travaux d'agrandissement du New Khedivial Hotel d’Alexandrie seront termines dans lea premier jours de Janvier. A ce moment la direction disposera de 150 chambres au lieu de 60, c'est-a-dire 90 chambres en plus.

Ou sait qu’il a fallu fermer l'Hotel pendant tout le mois de novembre pour mener a bien ces travaux. Malgre ce mois de chomage complet, les recettes au 20 decembre sont presque egales a celles de la meme periods de l’annee passes. Pour les dix jours du 10 au 20 decembre, elles out depasse de 133 livres celles de la decade correspondante du mois de decembre 1904.

Il n’existe dans l’affaire ni parts de fonda- teur, ni obligations; tous les benefices appar- tiennent aux actionnaires et la prime de 1/4 de livre, payree a l’emission sur toutes les ac- tions, a ete passee a la reserve.
On ne saurait encore se prononcer sur le dividende qui sera distribue en fin d’exercice, mais il sera vraisemblablement des plus satis- faisanrs.
On aunonce que la Societe des Ciments d’Egypte a obtenu une nouvelle commande importante : une fourniture de 6,000 tonnes an minimum par au a une grande entreprise locale.

Eu outre, la Societe est favorisee par une circonstance des plus heureuses : les Com- pagnies de navigation ont denonce les contrats d’apres lesquels les ciments importres de l’e- tranger beneficiaient jusqu’a present de frets modiques qui leur permettaient de lutter aise- ment contre les ciments egyptiens. Or, ces conditions favorables devant cesser des le ler janvier prochain, l’ffet de cette difference dans les prix de transport ne tardera pas a se faire sentir au profit de la Societe.

D’antre part, on fournit un renseignement tres important au sujet du plan financier de la Societe. Celle ci est graves, on le sait, d’une charge de £ 50,000 d’obligations, dont £ 20,000 ont ere emises a des conditions relativement onereuses. Or, il est question de rembourser ces £ 20,000 au moyen d’une emission d’actions d’egalimontant. Naturelle- ment, il faudra attendre pour cela que le cours de l'action, cotee actuellement a 75 francs, remonte an-dessus du pair, ce qui ne saurait tarder.

La nouvelle emission faite, la Societe devrs, en tout premier lieu, a'occuper de payer aux porteurs d’actions ordinaires les dividendes arrieres auxquels ils ont droit, c’est-a-dire 25% pour les cinq exercices passes, le dividende du 5 % etant cumulatil. Les parts de fondateur pourront ensuite commencer a toucher des be- nefices.
Aussi bien il y a lien de preferer les actions ordinaires aux parts de fondateur, les premie- res devant certainement despasser le pair a bref delai.
Hier, apres-midi, a en lieu, au siege social au Caire, la 6eme assemblee generale ordinaire, de la Salt and Soda Co.
Ainsi que nous l’avions annonce, un divi- dende de 4 % sera distribue aux, actions ordi- naires. Les profits des Huileries et Savonneries passent entierement a la reserve, qui s'eleve a L.E. 60.000.

An sujet de la recente decision du gouverne- ment, le rapport du conseil d’administration dit que l’experience montrera l’effet que la suppression du monople du sel aura sur les be- nefices de la Societe.
Sur le marche des cotous, le Mars a ouvert ce matin a 15 27/32 pour cloturer a 15 25/32.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’execution de fous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marches de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An- vers, Liverpool, et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyee sur demande.

div.head: ﻿STEAM ENGINES IN EGYPT.
div.p: A high standard of efficiency has been main- tained in the Technical Service of the Ministry of Public Works. The difference between the conditions ruling at present—as regards steam engine licenses—and those of a few years ago, is very striking. Inspections are now made by the Government Inspectors with practically no trouble or obstruction on the part of engine proprietors, and applications tor licenses come in regularly and voluntarily. 890 applications were made for licenses last year. These, with 96 which had remained over for consideration at the end of 1903-together with 18 received through the medium of the Moudiriehs—make a total of 604 (as against 358 in 1903. Of the above, 441 licenses were granted last year—163 remaining over at the end of the year for fur- ther consideration. 360 licensed engines passed all the required test satisfactorily and were pemitted to be worked. The remaining 81 were still going through the test at the end of 1904. There were on the 1st of January, 1905, 1,609 engines employed for industrial purposes in Egypt (exclusive of those employed for irrigation), all of which are working in confor- mity with the Government regulations. 51 cases of "contravention” were brought before the Courts in 1904—48 in the Native and 3 in the Mixed Courts. In these last, all the engines were stopped from working. Of the cases before the Native Courts, 10 engines were stopped, and the remaining 38 are still awaiting trial.

The Native Courts are extremely slow in trying cases of this kind—in some instances a year and more elapsing before judgment is delivered. As it not infrequently happens that engines—pronounced to be in a dangerous state by the Government Inspector — are permitted to continue working until the case has been decided, such delays- are very prejudical to public security.

Only one boiler explosion took place last year. The cause was working it at a higher pressure than that authorised by the license. One man was killed. All Irrigation engine licenses are now granted by the Technical Service, and the boilers of such engines are now subjected to the same tests and regula- tions as the others.

The dangerous practice of overloading safety valves is still of frequent occurrence, although the Technical Service is exerting all its energy to stop it. It is such a favorite practice with most, if not all of the native drivers that, until the majority of them are substituted by others better instructed in their work, no feeling of security from this evil can be attained.

div.head: SUFFERINGS OF TURKISH TROOPS
div.p: Terrible stories are told (says the "Time" correspondent at Constantinople) of the suffer- ings of the Ottoman troops which are being brought back from Yemen in crowded trans- ports, without adequate medical attendance or even sufficient food. In one well authenticated case more than one-third of the men died of wounds and disease before the transport reached the Suez Canal.

div.head: WHAT THE PARROT SAID.
div.p: Here is a parrot story which is both new and true. A venerable and pious lady, inspired to enthusiasm by a dealer’s emphatic decla- ration that a parrot he had could "sing a hymn, ” paid what he demanded for tbe gifted bird, and took it home in triomph. She invited a party of friends of a cast of mind, as serious as her own to hear the parrot’s rendering of the hymn. When all had assembled the covering was withdrawn from the cage, and Polly, opening one eye, looked round drow- sily. “ What a — crew !" she murmured, quietly, and went to sleep again.

div.head: TO-DAY ON THE NILE
div.p: This is an excellent companion to the guide- book for the tourist on the Nile. The author Mr. H. W. Dunning, Ph.D., late Instructor in Semitic languages in Yale University, announces in the preface that he claims only to write as a traveller who has been and is interested in Egypt. The book contains a good description of a trip up the river, and there are also chapters devoted to the ancient and mo- dern history of Egypt, its religion and gods, the Cairo Museum, and the Sudan. The book is written in a pleasant style and is not over- hardened with learning. It will just suit the intelligent tourist, who comes fresh to the country and wants to see the usual sights and learn something about the land and its history without having to take the trouble to wade through guide-books for his information. It is well printed and admirably illustrated with photogravures. The information is fully up to date, for the preface is dated on the 15th of last month. We cordially recommend this work as a most useful and delightful handbook for the visitor to Egypt.
*Today on the Nile. Published by James Pott & Co., New York, 1906.

div.head: COTTON TRADE IN 1905.
MOST PROSPEROUS YEAR ON RECORD.
div.p: The year just ending has been the most profitable over experienced in the history of the Lancashire cotton spinning industry. A statement issued of the working of 90 limited liability companies whose balance sheets have just been published reveals a remarkable degree of prosperity. The combined paid-up share cap- ital of these concerns is rather more than three and a half millions, and after charging the revenue with interest on the borrowed capital of £1,794,000 and allowing for wear and tear of plant, the total profit recorded for the year is £698,000, or equal to 19% on the capital. Only nine companies failed to pay dividends. This record profit has not only enabled the total adverse balances of £102,500 existing at the end of last year to be cleared off, but credit balances and reserve funds have been created amounting to £400,000, after the large sum of over £237,000 has been paid away in dividends and bonuses. The mean average dividend paid is equal to 7 per cent. The healthy feeling that has prevailed has resulted in the erec- tion of a large number of new mills, which will be putting yarn on the market during the coming year. The existing oompanies will, therefore, have more competition in the future, and, with a threatened short crop of Ameri- can cotton in view, it is feared that the outlook for the coming year is not quite so cheering to investors in this class of securi- ties. Users of Egyptian cotton are in rather a better position, and, on the whole, perhaps, the situation is not so dispiriting to holders.
During the past twenty two years, sixteen have been profitable periods, the aggregate profits amounting to £3,382,868, and loss for the six years being £256,765 or a net profit earned of £3,116,102.

div.head: COTTON BROKERS AS PRINCIPALS OR AGENTS.
div.p: There was concluded in the Chancery Court of Lancashire, sitting in St. George’s-hall, Liverpool, on Saturday week, an action which was brought by the Societe Cotonniere de St. Etienne du Rouvray against Messrs. Shand, Higsorg snd Co., cotton brokers, of Liverpool. The plaintiffs are a company incorporated according to the laws of France, carrying on business as cotton spinners and manufacturers at Rouen. It appeared from the statement of claim that transactions took place from April, 1902, to March, 1904, between the plaintiffs and defendants on the Liverpool cotton market, the total of the purchases and sales made by the defendants amounting, it was stated, to about 11,800 bales, and the plaintiffs remitted £6,775 as balances to the defen- dants. It was claimed on behalf of the plaintiffs that the defendants acted in the transactions as the plaintiffs’ brokers or agents; that an account might be taken of all dealings and transactions between the plaintiffs and the defendants in relation to the purchase and sale of cotton during the years 1902-4 inclusive, and that the defendants might be ordered to pay to the plaintiffs what might be found due to them on making such account. Damages for breach of duty by the defendants as brokers were also claimed. Mr. W. R. Shand, a member of the defendant firm, said in evidenoe that they had always regarded themselves as principals in the transactions. When his firm received an order to buy for a firm like the plaintiffs,' they sold to them at the market price ruling. His Honour said he was con- vinced that the defendants had acted straight- forwardly and had done nothing which they were not entitled to do under the contracts. He was not going to give a formal judgment that day, bnt he was in the plaintiffs’ favor as to whether the defendants were principals or agents—he was satisfied that they were agents. He therefore directed that the plain- tiffs were entitled to an account In taking that account the plaintiffs were entitled to repudiate the transactions in "futures" in which the defendants had acted as principals to sell or buy on behalf of the plaintiffs where they had dealt with their own cotton. They might treat it that he had decided the case, but in a matter of this interest and importance he preferred to give a formal judgment. Mr. Horridge intimated that there would be an appeal.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
(From our Financial Correspondent).
The Government and South Africa.
div.p: London, December 22.

The features of the week have been the rise of money, caused by the Bank of England withdrawing money from the market for the purposes of making, its rate effective and con- solidating its position, and to-day’s news of the Government adopting the somewhat un- constitutional course of prohibiting further importations of Chinese coolies into South Africa. As regards the former, the step taken by the Bank is commended on all hands, and while it has opened a temporary scarcity in the money market, it will certainly result in greater ease. The proportion of reserve to liabilities has gone down to 36 1/4%, but with effective control over the money market, this is considered quite satisfactory.

The nervous action of the Government in regard to Chinese labour on the Rand, which they affect to consider a menace to South Africa, might have been expected to cause a big slump in South African shares, but the unexpected always happens." The Exchange argues, no doubt correctly, that the number of Chinese already in the mines are sufficient for the present, and that this Government, if it receives a mandate from the people, is not likely to be long in power. Already they have begun attacking important interests, which have surely already suffered sufficiently from interfering legislation. The sympathy of those connected with South Africa will now also be alienated, and a very large number of the electors are watching apprehensively the Home Rule tendencies of the Prime Minister. If Ireland is to "manage its own affairs,” having already municipal government, what can this mean but the granting of a Parliament a Parliament on the lines of the present municipal councils, which are certainly not satisfactory.

The members of the Stock Exchange—and they are pretty shrewd calculators—are, there- fore, very probably correct in the view that the new Administration, if elected, has not the elements of Stability, and on the return of a more conservative rule six months or a year hence there will be ample time to fill up with fresh importations the Chinese who would have been repatriated in the meantime.
div.head: The Situation In Russia.
div.p: The general political situation is certainly not any worse. If the Imperial party cannot rule Russia and the latest effort at coercion has been an absolute failure — some popularly elected body must do so. It is felt that the final step of the Tsar in refusing universal suffrage, contrary even to the opinion of his own Cabi- net, is an act of suicide so far as the Imperial regime is concerned. The last scene, which everybody here is expecting, looks as if it would be a decisive one, and, we hope, in view of the apparent unanimity of the work- ing classes in the present strike, or rather revolution, it will not cause further bloodshed.
div.head: Consols.
div.p: There has been little movement in Consols, which leave off at 89 5/14, a rise of 1/8 on last week.
div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: In the market for Foreign Government se- curities Russians have further declined, and are to-night quoted at 8 1/2, as compared with 80 3/4 a week ago. Japanese stooks are steady. The new loan leaves off to-night at 5 3/5 premium.
div.head: Railways.
div.p: A steady tone has prevailed in the market for home railways, assisted by the week's returns, which were on the whole satisfactory. The announcement by the managing committee of the South Eastern and Chatham that a new and more modern roof is to be built over Charing Cross station, and that the station will be re-opened in six weeks’ time, caused a sharp advance in the company’s shares, which is being maintained.
div.head: The American Market.
div.p: In the American railway market Union Pacifics have settled down to 150 3/4, which would appear to be a high enough price. As regards the Chicago bank failure, the support of the other banks entirely prevented any disastrous results. Mr. Walsh’s speculations do not appear to have been of a wild descrip- tion. At any rate, the investigation seems to have shown that he is still possessed of a considerable fortune. The three banks, the Chicago National Bank, the Home Savings Bank, and the Equitable Trust Company, ap- pear to have been one and the same, i.e., under the control of Mr. Walsh. It speaks well for the state of finance in this large speculative centre that an affair of this kind can happen without leaving any unpleasant after-effects. As a matter of fact the American market generally is considered to be in a very sound and satisfactory position. The country is making money rapidly, and gold is returning to the money centres, as is usual at this time of the year.
div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: There has again been very little doing in the Egyptian market this week, and with the approach of the holidays business is not likely to improve. National Bank of Egypt have fallen to 24 7/8—5 1/8, and Agricultural Banks to 9, with hardly any bargains to report. Daira Sanieh Ordinary and Deferred shares have been flat, the Ordinary falling to 16 3/4, and the Deferred to 160, with very few buyers, even at these reduced figures. Egyptian Estates have been in good demand at 1 1/2. and the Deferred shares have advanced to 6 buyers. This seems a good price far 1s. shares. Delta Preference Bearer are very firm at 11 3/4 buyers, and these shares are full of dividend. Egyptian Markets are a little better at 1 3/4-1/2, but Salt end Soda remain dull at 1 1/26 Union Fonciere are 5/8 premium, and Abyssinian Banks 3/8 discount. Khedivial Mail are still buyers at 1 3/4, perhaps slightly more, and the Debentures are enquired for at 100. Roumanian Banks are about 7 3/4-7/8, but the business has again gone off in these. Delta Land at 2 1/8 and Daira Sugar at 4 1/4 are quite unchanged.
div.head: Mining
div.p: In view of this morning's news re the Go- vernment’s attitude, South African mines are fairly steady, bnt there are no prominent features. The money to be distributed in February in this market in dividends alone is well over one-and-a-half millions, and it is felt that this is the most solid argument for stability.

The Egyptian section has been flat for the greater part of the week, but there was a slight revival yesterday, though the prices all-round are under our last quotations. Nile Valleys are now 2/15, after being lower, and Um Rus leave off at the same figure. Egyptian Mines Explo- ration close at 9s. 0d., a tall since our last of about 1s.
div.head: Sulphide Corporation's Report.
div.p: The report of the Sulphide Corporation has attracted considerable notice, and it would seem as if the prospects of this concern are very fine, and we hear of influential buying. Not only have they in the past year, with the price of lead at £12, made considerable profits, although acting on conservative lines, they have not distributed them, and have before them an increase in the price to £17, but they are also now working a new process by which the cost of production will be very largely decreased.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report.
div.p: Liverpool, December 21.

There has been a very moderate demand for Egyptians this week. Quotations are un- changed except for Fine Brown, which is raised 1/8 per lb. In futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the latest values:—
Dec. 8.7 March 8.7 June 8.7 Jan. 8.7 April 8.7 July 8.7 Feb. 8.7 May 8.7 Aug. 8.7

American Futures The Market this week has been fairly active and there have been plenty of fluctuations, but within narrower limits, at one moment prices were 15 @ 17 points higher, but the advance has not been maintained, and today's closing values are 1 @ 3 up to 1 @ 2 points decline from those of last Thursday. The only feature has. been the National Ginners report the Census Bureau report of the cotton ginned to the 13th instant; the first estimate it at 8,975,000 and the official report at 9,282,000. The pro- bability is that even this latter estimate is too low as there is no compulsion to make returns neither, however, has had more than a passing influence upon the market. The power of planters, aided by the extensive "bull" operations in New York and New Orleans, to hold back their cotton, is the most important factor in the situation and may enable them to maintain present high values, even, possibly, to force them higher temporarily, but if the crop proves to be 11 millions, as present indications point to, we expect that later there will be heavy liquidation with a material decline. div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
(Communication Officielle)
div.p: La Commission Municipale s’est réunie le 27 décembre 1905 sous la présidence de S.E. Mah- mood Pacha Sidky.
La séance est ouverte à 4 h. p.m.

Présent : MM. Ambroise A. Ralli, vice- président, Ahmed Bey Eyoub, Em. Benachi Hussein Bey Riaz, A. Cumbo, L Escoffier, P Fenderi, Mansour Bey Youssef, Baron de Menasce, Mohamed Boy Mahfouz, O Rothaz- ker, A. Padoa Bey. Dr J. Schiess Bey, Em Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervudachi, G. Zouro, membres, W. P. Chata- way, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.

En ouvrant la séance, le président exprime les regrots de l’assemblée pour la perte qu’elle vient de faire en la personne de Saleh Bey Heddeni, membre désigné par le Gouverne- ment au sein de la Commission Municipale.
Le Président propose d’envoyer à la famille du défunt une lettre de condoléances.
La Commission se joint au Président dans l’expression de ses sentiments et décide de lever la séance en signe de deuil pendant cinq minutes.

A la reprise de la séance, le Président est heureux de pouvoir annoncer qu’à la suite des démarches qu’il avait été chargé, dé faire au- près de M. Suzzarini, celui-ci a bieu voulu ac- cepter de retirer sa démission.

Au sujet de la communication des procèss verbaux de la Délégation, M. Escoffier demande ou en est la question de l'emplacement à pro- poser à l’Eat pour l'hôpital des maladies in- fectieuses. L'Administrateur répond que la Délégation a décidé dans sa séance d'hier de recommander au choix du Gouvernement un terrain à Hadra, précédemment afficté aux ecuries de la police.

Sur une observation de M.Escoffier, la Com- mission renvoie à l'étude de l’Administration le point de savoir si la Compagnie des Eaux est fondée à réclamer le prix des bouches d'ar rosage que la Municipalité demande à installer dans les pares publics et dans les rues.
L’ordre du jour appelle la discussion du pro- jet de budget de 1906.

Mention est faite à ce sujet de l’envoi aux membres du rapport de l’Administrateur sur le dit budget, du procès-verbal de la Délégation y relatif, ainsi que du rapport du Comité des Finances en posant ses propositions et observa- tions au sujet du budget.

L'Administrateur dit que dans sa séance d'hier la Délégation a partagé sur la plupart des points les conclusions du rapport du Comité des Finances, conclusions qui ne comportent au point de vue des chiffres du budget qu’une dif- férence de L.E. 100, montant de deux alloca- tions que la Délégation propose de maintenir d'après ses premières propositions.

Cette question des allocations a donné lieu à une discussion de principe, quelques membres ayant demandé de ne les inscrire au budget que pour un chiffre global, sauf à faire une répartition ultérieure qui serait basée sur une étude qu'un Comité spécial aurait à pour- suivre dans ce bus.

Après un échange d'idées,la Commission se rallie à une proposition du Vice-Président tendant à l'adoption des allocations telles qu’elles sont proposées par le Comité des Finances et amendées par la Délégation et à nommer à la prochaine séance un Comité chargé de reviser les subventions actuelles et de proposer leur répartition sur le mode qu’il croira le plus équitable.
Le rapport de ce Comité devra être pre- senté avant le 15 novembre 1906.
Une augmentation de 50 L E. pour le Sport- ing Club, et une nouvelle subvention de 50 L.E. pour l’asile enfantin israclite sont votées.
Les autres chapitres du budget des-recettes et dépeuses sont adoptés, tels qu'ils sont proposés par le Comité des Finances d'accord avec la Délégation.
Eu conséquence le budget est arrêté en recettes à LE 195,000 et en dépenses an même chiffre avec une réserve de LE 1884
A l'occasion de la discussion du budget, M Escoffier propose que le budget d’assistance publiqne de la ville soit alimenté par un impôt à établir sur les cercles.
La Commission émet un avis favorable à cette proposition qu’elle renvoie pour plus ample étude au Comité des Finances et du Conten- tieux.

Une proposition de M. Zouro tendant à por- ter à L E 25 le minimum de loyer imposable de la taxe du 2% et de réduce à un pour cent la redevance sureles loyers annuele de 25 à 50 L.E. est renvoyée à l’étude du Comité des Fi- nances.
Sur rapport du Comité des Plantations, et à la suite des explications donnees par M. le Dr. Schiess Bey, Président de ce Comité, la Commission décide :

1. d’euvrir un crédit de LE 600 pour les travaux de plantations à exécuter au grand jardin Nouzha en attendant qu’on plan général des améliorations et modifications à apporter dans ledit jardin soit adopté et mis en œuvre.

2 de consacrer pour cette année une somme de L E 5.000 pour la confection du nouveau jardin à créer sur le terrain cédé par le Gou- vernement près de l’hôpital indigène et pour les travaux préliminaires de terrassement et de mise eu profil que comporte le projet André eu commençant par la partie des fortifica- tions situés au nord de la Porte Rosette.
Les deux dépenses ci-dessus seront prélevées sur le budget extraordinaire.
La surveillanoe et la direction de l’exécution des parcs sera assumée par le service muni- cipal des jardins et les travaux mis en adjuca- tion.
L’ordre du jour appelle l’interpellation dé M. Zouro concernant la suite donnée à diverses décisions prises par la Commission sur ses pro- positions.

M. Zouro commence le développement de ses interpellations, mais vu l’heure tardive, et désirant s’entourer au préalable de tons éclair- cissements sur les questions se rapportant aux dires interpellations, la Commission prie M. Zouro de vouloir bien communiquer ses déve loppements à l’Administration qui les distri buera aux membres avec ses observations.
La séance est levée à 7 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: SOCIETE ANONYME
DES PRESSES LIBRES EGYPTIENNES
Exercice 1904-1905.
div.p: L’Exercice 1904-1905 a clôturé avec un pressage de balles 19o.585, contre balles 174.010 de la dernière campagne.

Les bénéfices nets, après le prélèvement de l’intérêt et l’amortissement des obligations; l’amortissement complet des hangars et une rétrocession aux presseurs de P.T. 95 par 1,000 cantars pressés ont atteint le chiffre de P.T. 841.806 2/10, contre P.T. 624.954 8/10 de l’année-dernière.

Dans le courent de l’Exercice, la Société a fait acquisition, dans des conditions favorables, de la grande Chounah Menasce, à côté de son nouvel Etablissement, d’une contenance d’en- viron 18.300 (treize mille trois cents) pics carrés, ainsi que de la Chounah Butterworth and Smalley, vis-à-vis son ancien établissement d’une surface d’environ 2.600 (deux mille six cents) pics carrés.
Poor parfaire à ces achats, elle a émis et placé £ 30.000 (trente mille), en Obligations Hypothécaires 4 1/2 0/0, remboursables dans un délai maximum de trente ans.

Les bénéfices nets de l'Exercice 1er Sep- tembre 1904—31 Août 1905, après l'intérêt et l'amortissement des obligations, l'amortisse- ment complet des hangars, et une rétrocession aux Presseurs de P.T. 95 par 1.000 cantars pressés, s’élèvent, comme nous venons de le dire, à P.T. 841.806.2.

Après avoir doté le Fonds de Dépréciation du 3 0/0 sur P.T. 3.608.674 2/10 (coût des machines et constructions) soit P.T. 108.260.2, le Fonds de Réserve du 10 0/0 sur P.T., 733.046 soit P.T. 73.354.6 et passé à un nouveau compte intitulé Réserve pour Dépréciation Propriétés Immobilières P.T. 30.000—, il reste P.T. 630.191.4.

Sur ce chiffre il revient aux Actionnaires à titre d’intérêt, 6% sur £ 50,000 Capital social, soit £ 3,000 et, à titre da Dividende, 70 % sur le surplus de P.T. 337,691 4 (les autres 30 % étant attribués aux Parts de Fondation), soit P.T. 236.384, plus le reliquat de l'exercice précédent P.T. 56.050, 5, soit un total de P.T. 584.934, 5 revenant aux Actionnaires.

Sur cette somme, il sera distribué aux Actionnaires le 10 % du Capital de £ 50,000, soit P.T. 487.500. Après déduction de P.T. 17.373, 9 du reste pour achever l’amortisse- ment du coût des Parts de Fondation, il reste P.T. 80.060, 6 à reporter à nouveau.

Il levient aux porteurs de Parts de Fon- dation 30 % sur le surplus ci-dessus de P.T. 337.691 4/10, soit P.T. 101.307, 4, plus le reliquat de l’exercice précédent soit P.T. 274, ensemble P.T. 101.581, 4; ce qui permet de distribuer aux Parts de Fondation P.T. 282 par titre, soit : sur titres 360 P.T. 101.520 ;
Restent P.T. 61, 4 à reporter à nouveau.

Le revenu des 356 Parts de Fondation, dont la Société est propriétaire, soit P.T. 100.392, conjointement a la somme ci-dessus de P.T. 17.373, 9, soit ensemble P.T. 117.766, 9 sera passée au Compte Amortissement Parts da Fondation, pour achever, comme il est dit plus haut, l’amortissement du coût de ces Parts.

Par cette répartition, l’ensemble dee réserves en fonds de depréciation, fonds de réserve et obligations amorties, atteindra le chiffre de P.T. 1.860.781 7/10, indépendamment de l'a- mortissement du coût des Parts de Fondation et des hangars.
Cette répartition attribue aux actions £ 2, soit le 10 % du Capital, et aux Parts de Fondation P.T. 282.
Un ooupon intérimaire d’notion de £ 0.12 (3 %, ayant été payé le 20 mai dernier, il reste à toucher £ 1.8 (7 %) pour solde, contre remise du coupon No. 21.
Le Dividende de P.T. 232 par Part de Fondation sera payé contre remise du coupon, No., 8.

div.head: THEATRE ALHAMBRA
div.p: La représentation du "Petit Duo" a obtenu hier un grand succès. Mlle Lambertini a été, comme d'ordinaire, ravissante en duo de Parte- nay. Le rôle de Frimousse a été admirablement tenu par M. Simon et celui de Montlandry par M. Crépy. Diane de Château. Lansac, en la circonstance Mme Simon, a dû bisser la leçon de solfège, cù elle a été vivement applaudie. Très bien également Mlle Nolba en duchesse.
Ce soir, nouvelle représentation de "La Poupée," opéra-comique de Maurice Ordon- neau, musique d'Audran. Mlle Lambertini jouera le rôle d’Alésia.
Prochainement "Les Travaux d’Hercule," opéra-bouffe nouveau.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
Au jour d'hui à midi et domie)
div.p: A part la Daïra qui fléchit à 16 7/8 et les Markets à 25/6, toutes les autres fluctuations de la cote indiquent une reprise.
Comme hier, la Nungovich a eu les honneurs de la matinée. Par suite d'une forte demande provenant du Caire, le cours s'avance au- jourd'hui de 11 1/16 à 11 7/16.
Les Banques sont particulièrement bien tenues : la Nationale reprend de 25 3/16 à 25 1/4, l’action Crédit Foncier de 778 à 781, l’Agricole est ferme à 9 7/32, et la Land Bank regagne 1/16 à 7 15/16.
La Salt & Soda est mieux tenue à 20/3, l’Anglo-American Nile reprend à 5 3/4 et la Ramleh Railway à 6 3/4.
Quant aux autres valeurs, elles demeurent fermes aux cours antérieurs. La tendance générale est bonne.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompany- ing description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care had been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In Choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uni- formly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year; for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time oc- cupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows :-
The long sea routes-from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool-occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:-

Port Said or ALexandria to Brindisi 3 days Alexandria to Messina... ... ... 3 " Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 " Alexandria to Venice and Trieste 4 " Alexandria to Naples... ... 3 " Port Said to Genoa ... ... ... 5 " Port Said to Naples... ... ... 4 " Alexandria to Constantinople ... 4 " Alexandria to Piraeus ... ... ... 2 " Port Said to Gibraltar... ... ... 7 "

The steamers, of the P. & 0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Mari times are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alex- andria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm- ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is he station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demostheues in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in b.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain in his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Polazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.
div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steam- ers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its island, besides the lovely places on its Bay— Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte- rest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallom- brosa; with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog- wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

Syracuse GRAND HOTEL VILLA POLITI Newly Ronovated and thoroughly refurnished electric Light throughout. Central Heating in every room. Beautiful Gardens. Concerts dailt. New Proprietor. Gustav Kochel also of the Hotel Grande Bretagne Hotel Metropole
